Definition: Animals that communicate acoustically adapt their vocalisations to the local conditions to optimise signal transmission.
Lokatis_definition: Animals that communicate acoustically adapt their vocalisations to the local conditions to optimise signal transmission.
Lokatis_comments: Birds in cities: Slabbekoorn & Peet (2003). Insects from noisy habitats produce different acoustic signals than conspecifics from quiet habitats, possibly using a more permanent mechanism for signal adjustment than behavioural plasticity (Lampe et al. 2014).

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species depends on the adaptation to the conditions in the exotic range before and/or after the introduction. Non-native species that are related to native species are more successful in this adaptation
Daly_definition: Invasion success is influenced by the relatedness of non-native species to native species in the novel range. Relatedness may promote (Duncan and Williams 2002) or inhibit invasion (Darwin 1859, Daehler 2003)
Daly_example_1: Moose Alces alces populations that have been free from non-human predation for several decades quickly regain antipredator behaviour when its natural predators are reintroduced. Contrast this with Galapagos Island fauna, which when exposed to evolutionarily novel predators cannot adapt antipredator defenses (Carthey and Banks 2014).
Daly_example_2: Functional trait overlap in forbs confers community resistance to invasion (Price and Pärtel 2012).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species depends on the adaptation to the conditions in the exotic range before and/or after the introduction. Non-nativespecies that are related to native species are more successful in this adaptation

Definition: Anthropogenically induced adaptation to invade can facilitate invasion and invasiveness of an organism or population.
Hypothesis_label: Anthropogenically induced adaptation to invade hypothesis
Daly_definition: Anthropogenically induced adaptation to invade can facilitate invasion and invasiveness of an organism or population (Hufbauer et al. 2012).
Daly_example_1: The ability of the Asian house gecko Hemidactylus frenatus to grip smooth surfaces is thought to have arisen due to urban evolution, as this trait allows the geckos to easily climb human-made materials (Petren and Case 1998). This species has become invasive in many areas, potentially aided by its superior ability to survive in urban areas (Borden and Flory 2021).
Daly_example_2: Fungal graminiod pathogen, Mycosphaerella graminicola, is thought to have adapted to wheat during its domestication (Stukenbrock et al. 2007). It is now the only of its congeners to be invasive (Hufbauer et al. 2012).

Definition: The Allee effect, a positive association between fitness and population size, can cause a lag between introduction of non-native species and establishment in abundant populations.
Daly_definition: The Allee effect, a positive association between fitness and population size, can cause a lag between introduction of non-native species and establishment in abundant populations (Allee 1938, Petrovskii et al. 2005).

Definition: Adaptation to homogenized anthropogenic environments can serve as a form of preadaptation of the organism to homogenous human-altered habitats globally (Hufbauer et al. 2012).
Hypothesis_label: Adaptation to homogenized anthropogenic environments hypothesis
Daly_definition: Adaptation to homogenized anthropogenic environments can serve as a form of preadaptation of the organism to homogenous human-altered habitats globally (Hufbauer et al. 2012).

Definition: Species associated with humans are more likely to become invasive because of their increased opportunity for anthropogenic transport (Hufbauer et al. 2012). See also HCOM.
Daly_definition: Species associated with humans are more likely to become invasive because of their increased opportunity for anthropogenic transport (Hufbauer et al. 2012). See also HCOM.

Definition: The increasing global abundance of invasive species is related to anthropogenic transportation through inter- and intra-continental exchanges (Perrings et al. 2005, Seebens et al. 2017).
Key_ref: Perrings et al. 2005; Seebens et al. 2017
Daly_definition: The increasing global abundance of invasive species is related to anthropogenic transportation through inter- and intra-continental exchanges (Perrings et al. 2005, Seebens et al. 2017).
Daly_example_1: Population characteristics of invasive earthworms and Plants are predicted by proximity to roads and their characteristics (Cameron and Bayne 2009, Paudel et al. 2016).
Daly_example_2: Genetic evidence indicates that the abundance of invasive Plants in the sub-Antarctic is a result of repeated introductions by human activities (Mairal et al. 2021).

Hypothesis: Biotic acceptance aka ‘the rich get richer’
Definition: Ecosystems tend to accommodate the establishment and coexistence of non-native species despite the presence and abundance of native species
Daly_definition: Biotic acceptance is a diversity-invasibility relationship where that the richness of native and non-native species is positively related (Stohlgren et al. 2006).
Daly_example_1: The richness of non-native and native Plants is often correlated, likely because favourable environments for native species are similarly favourable for non-native species (Souza et al. 2011, Bjarnason et al. 2017).
Enders_hypothesis: Biotic acceptance aka ‘the rich get richer’
Enders_definition: Ecosystems tend to accommodate the establishment and coexistence of non-native species despite the presence and abundance of native species

Definition: Cities can sustain and promote biodiversity.
Lokatis_definition: Cities can sustain and promote biodiversity.
Lokatis_comments: "Walters (1970) was the first to point out that cities harbour more spontaneous (not cultivated) plant species than the surrounding landscape." Kühn et al. 2004, p.749

Definition: Invasion may be inhibited when non-native species are behaviourally constrained and require adaptations before recognizing and readily consuming, evading, or outcompeting an introduced population (Lankau et al. 2004).
Daly_definition: Invasion may be inhibited when non-native species are behaviourally constrained and require adaptations before recognizing and readily consuming, evading, or outcompeting an introduced population (Lankau et al. 2004).
Daly_example_1: Both non-native shore crabs Hemigrapsus sanguineus and white campion (Silene latifolia) are more susceptible to parasitism than native counterparts in exotic USA range (Keogh et al. 2017, Wolfe et al. 2004).
Daly_example_2: Invasive Plants, such as Sapium sebiferum in USA, benefit from lower herbivory rates due to behavioural avoidance despite it being a suitable host plant (Lankau et al. 2004).

Definition: Urban dwellers are characterized by a higher behavioral flexibility than urban avoiders.
Lokatis_definition: Urban dwellers are characterized by a higher behavioral flexibility than urban avoiders.
Comments_equivalent_hypotheses:
TH: not equivalent in my point of view.
MBV: I agree that they are not equivalent.

Definition: Non-native species benefit from different indirect effects triggered by native species
Daly_definition: Invasion success of non-native organisms is mediated by biotic indirect effects from native populations.
Enders_definition: Non-native species benefit from different indirect effects triggered by native species

Definition: Biomes differ in their inherent invasibility because of biotic and abiotic differences (Hui and Richardson 2017).
Daly_definition: Biomes differ in their inherent invasibility because of biotic and abiotic differences (Hui and Richardson 2017).

Definition: An ecosystem with high biodiversity is more resistant against non-native species than an ecosystem with lower biodiversity
Daly_definition: A diversity-invasibility relationship known as biotic resistance exists such that highly biodiverse ecosystems are more resistant to biological invasion because more niches are already filled, thus providing more competition with non-native species (Elton 1958, Levine and D'Antonio 1999).
Enders_definition: An ecosystem with high biodiversity is more resistant against non-native species than an ecosystem with lower biodiversity

Definition: The socioeconomic status of urban residents is positively related to the biodiversity in their neighbourhoods.
Lokatis_definition: The socioeconomic status of urban residents is positively related to the biodiversity in their neighbourhoods.
Lokatis_comments: "neighborhood socioeconomic and cultural status appears to be playing an important role in structuring urban biodiversity patterns, independent of the effects of population density, distance from urban center, or time since disturbance" Kinzig et al. 2005, p.5/13

Definition: Low variability in resource abundance and reduced predation allow higher population densities in urban areas through the persistence of many weak competitors who remain in poor body condition, who are less reproductively successful, and who would not otherwise survive.
Lokatis_definition: Low variability in resource abundance and reduced predation allow higher population densities in urban areas through the persistence of many weak competitors who remain in poor body condition, who are less reproductively successful, and who would not otherwise survive.
Lokatis_comments: "Only the winners have sufficient access to food resources and the opportunity to reproduce. The highly predictable continuous input of food in the urban environment allows them to “live on their credit”. They may trade off between offspring body condition and clutch size. In the lack of predation, the losers among the fledglings may survive for a relatively long period, getting just enough energy to survive. Though they may never become healthy enough to reproduce, they will have a major contribution to the observed population density. Results of several case studies seem to support the credit card hypothesis and suggest that it can serve as a general rule for the evolution of animal populations and communities in highly predictable human managed environments." Shochat 2004

Definition: C-competitor Plants are being selected in urban landscapes.
Lokatis_definition: C-competitor Plants are being selected in urban landscapes.

Definition: Cities are entry points for introduced non-native species.
Lokatis_definition: Cities are entry points for introduced non-native species.
Lokatis_comments: Urban areas are often the first entry point for newly introduced alien species

Definition: Climate change facilitates invasion of non-native species adapted to the new environmental conditions and exacerbate their impacts.
Daly_definition: Climate change facilitates invasion of non-native species adapted to the new environmental conditions and exacerbate their impacts. (Dukes and Mooney 1999, Hulme 2017).
Daly_example_1: Range expansion of invasive moth Lymantria dispar's and invasive tree mallow Malva arborea range expansion in their novel ranges is linked to local warming (Tobin et al. 2014, van der Wal et al. 2008).

Definition: Colonization pressure is defined as the number of species introduced to a given location. As colonization pressure increases, the number of established or invasive non-native species in that location is predicted to increase
Daly_definition: Colonization pressure, the number of species introduced into an area, is positively related to the number of established non-native species (Lockwood et al. 2009).
Enders_definition: Colonization pressure is defined as the number of species introduced to a given location. As colonization pressure increases, the number of established or invasive non-native species in that location is predicted to increase

Definition: The establishment of a non-native species depends on natural fluctuations of the ecosystem, which influence the level of competition from local species
Daly_definition: Non-native species establishment can depend on fluctuations in the dynamic equilibrium of recipient ecosystems that influence the competition of local species (Huston 1979).
Enders_definition: The establishment of a non-native species depends on natural fluctuations of the ecosystem, which influence the level of competition from local species

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species is higher in highly disturbed than in relatively undisturbed ecosystems
Daly_definition: Invasion success is increased in disturbed ecosystems relative to undisturbed ecosystems (Elton 1958, Hobbs and Huenneke 1992). See also hypothesis of ‘increased resource availability' from Sher and Hyatt (1999).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species is higher in highly disturbed than in relatively undisturbed ecosystems

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species is higher in areas that are poor in closely related species than in areas that are rich in closely related species
Daly_definition: Invasion success is influenced by the relatedness of non-native species to native species in the novel range. Relatedness may promote (Duncan and Williams 2002) or inhibit invasion (Darwin 1859, Daehler 2003)
Daly_example_1: Moose Alces alces populations that have been free from non-human predation for several decades quickly regain antipredator behaviour when its natural predators are reintroduced. Contrast this with Galapagos Island fauna, which when exposed to evolutionarily novel predators cannot adapt antipredator defenses (Carthey and Banks 2014).
Daly_example_2: Functional trait overlap in forbs confers community resistance to invasion (Price and Pärtel 2012).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species is higher in areas that are poor in closely related species than in areas that are rich in closely related species
Lokatis_key_ref_overarching: Crooks & Soulé 1999; Donnelly & Marzluff 2004 (cited aftger Catterall et al. 2010)

Definition: Species richness declines within patches of remnant native habitat isolated within an urban matrix; habitat-dependent (such as ‘forest interior’) species are expected to suffer a progressive series of local extinctions over time.
Lokatis_definition: Species richness declines within patches of remnant native habitat isolated within an urban matrix; habitat-dependent (such as ‘forest interior’) species are expected to suffer a progressive series of local extinctions over time.

Definition: Urban habitat remnants are more sensitive to the penetration of matrix species than less disturbed suburban or rural remnants.
Lokatis_definition: Urban habitat remnants are more sensitive to the penetration of matrix species than less disturbed suburban or rural remnants.
Lokatis_comments: "Urbanization changes considerable the structure of forested habitats, and it makes them vulnerable to the invasion of the matrix species. Species penetrating from the surrounding matrix (here the open-habitat species) may benefit from the habitat alteration. We are mentioning this new hypothesis as matrix species hypothesis." (Tóthmérész et al. 2011)

Definition: Epigenetic mechanisms can explain why some organisms are more successful in urban than non-urban areas.
Lokatis_definition: Epigenetic mechanisms can explain why some organisms are more successful in urban than non-urban areas.
Lokatis_comments: "genetic and epigenetic mechanisms can affect oxidative stress and inflammatory responses in urban environments, thereby affecting overall fitness" Isaksson 2015

Hypothesis: Exotic richness increases with age of urbanization
Definition: ﻿The diversity of exotic species will increase with the age of an urbanized area.
Hypothesis_label: Exotic richness increases with age of urbanization hypothesis
Lokatis_name: Exotic richness increases with age of urbanization
Lokatis_subhyp_of: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: ﻿The diversity of exotic species will increase with the age of an urbanized area.

Definition: Introduced enemies of a non-native species are less harmful to the non-native than to the native species
Enders_definition: Introduced enemies of a non-native species are less harmful to the non-native than to the native species

Definition: Urban habitats filter communities as a function of their traits.
Lokatis_definition: Urban habitats filter communities as a function of their traits.
Lokatis_key_ref_overarching: Rapport et al. 1985; Leibold et al. 2004; Petchey et al. 2007
Comments: Rapport et al. 1985 do not use the term 'filter', but present some of the basic ideas. Both Petchey 2007 and Rapport et al. 1985 are not focussing on urban environments.

Definition: Introduced enemies of non-native species are less harmful for them in the exotic than the native range, due to altered biotic and abiotic conditions
Daly_definition: Due to differing conditions in the novel range, enemy inversion may occur whereby introduced enemies are less harmful for non-native species (Colautti et al. 2004).
Enders_definition: Introduced enemies of non-native species are less harmful for them in the exotic than the native range, due to altered biotic and abiotic conditions

Definition: After having been released from natural enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy in growth and/or reproduction (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes), which makes them more competitive
Hypothesis_label: Evolution of increased competitive ability hypothesis
Daly_definition: Introduced species can undergo evolution of increased competitive ability by reinvesting resources used for defense and in growth, biomass, reproduction, and competitiveness when they escape natural enemies in their invasive range (Blossey and Nötzold 1995).
Enders_definition: After having been released from natural enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy in growth and/or reproduction (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes), which makes them more competitive

Definition: Invasion patterns are a function of the evolutionary characteristics of both the recipient region and potential donor regions. Species from regions with highly diverse evolutionary lineages are more likely to become successful invaders in less diverse regions
Daly_definition: An evolutionary imbalance in competitive ability between non-native species from areas with diverse lineages and native species from less diverse areas should increase their relative invasiveness (Fridley and Sax 2014).
Daly_example_1: Founder diversity consistently increases establishment success and reduces chance of local extinction (Forsman 2013). This pattern holds for invasive animals, such as Daphnia magna, and Plants, such as Spartina alterniflora (Wang et al. 2012, Robinson et al. 2013).
Daly_example_2: Invasive ant Linepithema humile and native aphid Chaitophorus populicola form mutualistic association potentially because of exaptation of features for cross-species communication (Mondor and Addicott 2007).
Enders_definition: Invasion patterns are a function of the evolutionary characteristics of both the recipient region and potential donor regions. Species from regions with highly diverse evolutionary lineages are more likely to become successful invaders in less diverse regions

Definition: The successful integration of non-native organisms in a new area depends on the characteristics, or ecosystem invasibility, of the recipient environment.
Key_ref: Alpert et al. 2000; Richardson and Pyšek 2006
Daly_definition: The successful integration of non-native organisms in a new area depends on the characteristics, or ecosystem invasibility, of the recipient environment (Alpert et al. 2000, Richardson and Pyšek 2006).
Daly_example_1: Environmental heterogeneity promotes dispersal and range expansion of animals with density-dependent dispersal as populations outgrow their patches in heterogenous environments (O'Reilly-Nugent et al. 2016).
Daly_example_2: Sub-arctic ecosystems are not uniformly invasible. Plant invasion success in these ecosystems is influenced by community composition and disturbance level (Milbau et al. 2013).

Definition: Introduced species can benefit from novel or enhanced mutualisms with native species, which can increase their performance relative to native populations (Reinhart and Callaway 2006). See also host-jumping and new associations hypothesis (Hui and Richardson 2017).
Daly_definition: Introduced species can benefit from novel or enhanced mutualisms with native species, which can increase their performance relative to native populations (Reinhart and Callaway 2006). See also host-jumping and new associations hypothesis (Hui and Richardson 2017).

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range
Daly_definition: Non-native species expand into new areas by filling an empty niche (Elton 1958) and non-native species will be unlikely to establish in a community dominated by functionally similar species because of greater niche overlap (MacArthur and Levins 1967, Abrams 1983, Stachowicz and Tilman 2005).
Daly_example_1: Phenological traits can allow non-native species to exploit a resource earlier (empty niche), and potentially longer, than native species. This has been observed in native vs. non-native members of family Torymidae in France (Gidoin et al. 2015) and with members of the genus Acer in North America (Paquette et al. 2012).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range

Hypothesis: Ecological naivety aka evolutionary naivety aka eco-evolutionary naivety
Definition: The impact of a non-native species on biodiversity is influenced by the evolutionary experience of the invaded community. Thus, the largest impacts are caused by species (e.g., predators, herbivores, pathogens) invading systems where no phylogenetically or functionally similar species exist
Key_ref: Diamond and Case 1986; Ricciardi and Atkinson 2004
Daly_definition: The impact of the invader is likely to be higher in eco-evolutionary naive communities, i.e. in communities where no phylogenetically or functionally similar species are present (Diamond and Case 1986, Carthey and Banks 2014).
Enders_hypothesis: Ecological naivety aka evolutionary naivety aka eco-evolutionary naivety
Enders_definition: The impact of a non-native species on biodiversity is influenced by the evolutionary experience of the invaded community. Thus, the largest impacts are caused by species (e.g., predators, herbivores, pathogens) invading systems where no phylogenetically or functionally similar species exist
Enders_key_ref: Diamond and Case (1986); Ricciardi and Atkinson (2004)

Definition: Specialized interactions in ecological networks may leave niche space unoccupied by inhibiting co-evolution. The empty niches can be exploited by non-native species through ecological fitting.
Daly_definition: Specialized interactions in ecological networks may leave niche space unoccupied by inhibiting co-evolution. The empty niches can be exploited by non-native species through ecological fitting (Hui and Richardson 2017).

Definition: Seasonal life cycles tend to start earlier in the urban core than in rural surroundings.
Lokatis_definition: Seasonal life cycles tend to start earlier in the urban core than in rural surroundings.
Lokatis_comments: Pattern thought to be related to the urban heat island, both due to milder temperatures in winter/spring, but possibly also as a reponse to earlier summer drought. First demonstrated for Plants, but also valid in some other groups
Comments: Phenology is determined by the microclimate. Warmer temperatures tend to accelerate development and cause earlier seasonal phenological stages (e.g. flowering). "﻿Mean flowering dates for the entire area were retarded more at cooler locations than warmer slopes were advanced."abstract, Jackson 1966.

Definition: The absence of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success
Lokatis_definition: The absence of enemies is a cause of invasion success.
Lokatis_comments: Application to cities: Adams et al. 2009; Shwartz et al. 2009
Daly_definition: Non-native species may rapidly increase in abundance and distribution due to enemy release: the absence, or reduction, of regulation by natural enemies (Keane and Crawley 2002).
Daly_example_1: Invasive rodents in Senegal have lower parasite loads than native rodents, which may partially explain their relative success (Diagne et al. 2016).
Enders_definition: The absence of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success

Definition: The partial release of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success
Daly_definition: Non-native species may rapidly increase in abundance and distribution due to enemy release: the absence, or reduction, of regulation by natural enemies (Keane and Crawley 2002).
Daly_example_1: Invasive rodents in Senegal have lower parasite loads than native rodents, which may partially explain their relative success (Diagne et al. 2016).
Enders_definition: The partial release of enemies in the exotic range is a cause of invasion success

Hypothesis: Enemy release hypothesis in urban core 2: herbivore perspective
Definition: In the absence of their native enemies in the urban core, alien herbivore insects introduced along alien Plants are prone to outbreaks.
Hypothesis_label: Enemy release hypothesis in urban core 2: herbivore perspective
Lokatis_name: Enemy release hypothesis in urban core 2: herbivore perspective
Lokatis_subhyp_of: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: In the absence of their native enemies in the urban core, alien herbivore insects introduced along alien Plants are prone to outbreaks.

Hypothesis: Enemy release hypothesis in urban core 1: plant perspective
Definition: ﻿Decreased regulation by herbivores and other enemies in the city allow exotic Plants to increase in distribution and abundance.
Hypothesis_label: Enemy release hypothesis in urban core 1: plant perspective
Lokatis_name: Enemy release hypothesis in urban core 1: plant perspective
Lokatis_subhyp_of: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: ﻿Decreased regulation by herbivores and other enemies in the city allow exotic Plants to increase in distribution and abundance.

Definition: Habitats preferred over other, higher quality habitats can be low in quality for reproduction or survival and may not sustain a population.
Lokatis_definition: Habitats preferred over other, higher quality habitats can be low in quality for reproduction or survival and may not sustain a population.
Lokatis_comments: Application to cities: Sumasgutner et al. 2014; Bonnington et al. 2015; Hale et al. 2015. Schlaepfer et al. 2002: "in an environment that has been altered suddenly by human activities, an organism makes a maladaptive habitat choice based on formerly reliable environmental cues, despite the availability of higher quality habitat". Aka 'attractive sink', source-sink hypothesis

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species is high if the exotic range has a highly heterogeneous environment
Daly_definition: Environmental heterogeneity promotes invasions by increasing both ecosystem invasibility and coexistence with native species (Melbourne et al. 2007). See also FLUC.
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species is high if the exotic range has a highly heterogeneous environment
Comments_equivalent_hypotheses: TH: not equivalent in my point of view

Definition: Fluctuating resources affect ecosystem invasibility, with unused resources facilitating invasion (Davis et al. 2000).
Daly_definition: Fluctuating resources affect ecosystem invasibility, with unused resources facilitating invasion (Davis et al. 2000).

Definition: Urban food webs largely lack weak interactions, but the partly disassembled food webs retain a greater density of species interactions (e.g. greater connectance).
Lokatis_definition: Urban food webs largely lack weak interactions, but the partly disassembled food webs retain a greater density of species interactions (e.g. greater connectance).
Lokatis_comments: "Specifically, urban food webs were less diverse and had fewer total links (Figure 3a,b). However, because generalists were lost more slowly in cities than specialists, species richness declined more quickly than the number of total links, increasing link densities and connectance in cities" Start et al. 2020

Definition: Small founding populations can cause a genetic bottleneck of incipient invasion leading to high inbreeding levels in introduced populations.
Daly_definition: Small founding populations can cause a genetic bottleneck of incipient invasion leading to high inbreeding levels in introduced populations (Willi et al. 2006).
Daly_example_1: Genetic bottlenecks in introduced populations of ladybug Harmonia axyridis are thought to purge deleterious alleles as introduced populations tend not to experience the same inbreeding depression as native populations (Facon et al. 2011).

Definition: A large number of different non-native species is more successful than a small number
Enders_definition: A large number of different non-native species is more successful than a small number

Definition: Genetic shifts take place in the novel range that facilitate invasion of non-native species.
Daly_definition: Genetic shifts take place in the novel range that facilitate invasion of non-native species (Elst et al. 2016).
Daly_example_1: Experimental evidence with the bean beetle Callosobruchus maculatus shows that spatial sorting promotes evolution relating to dispersal distance, which increases invasion speed (Ochocki and Miller 2017).
Daly_example_2: Japanese knotweed Fallopia × bohemica is more invasive than its non-native parents Fallopia japonica and Fallopia sachalinensis (Mandak et al. 2004).

Definition: Green roofs promote urban biodiversity.
Key_ref: Oberndorfer et al. 2007; Williams et al. 2014
Lokatis_definition: Green roofs promote urban biodiversity.
Lokatis_key_ref: Oberndorfer et al. 2007; Williams et al. 2014
Lokatis_comments: "Green roofs (roofs with a vegetated surface and substrate) provide ecosystem services in urban areas, including improved storm-water management,better regulation of building temperatures, reduced urban heat-island effects, and increased urban wildlife habitat." Oberndorfer et al. 2007 p.823

Definition: "Genetic signatures of urban eco-evolutionary feedback can be detected across Multiple taxa and ecosystem functions." (p. 116 in Alberti 2015)
Lokatis_definition: "Genetic signatures of urban eco-evolutionary feedback can be detected across Multiple taxa and ecosystem functions." (p. 116 in Alberti 2015)

Definition: Species richness in urban habitats is low in specialists but high in generalists.
Lokatis_definition: Species richness in urban habitats is low in specialists but high in generalists.
Comments: Species richness in disturbed habitats is low in specialists but high in generalists.

Hypothesis: Hyperabundance due to anthropogenic food* (aka predator subsidy consumption aka prey hyperabundance)
Definition: An increase in the proportion of anthropogenic food with urbanization leads to an increase in the abundance of prey as well as mid-sized animals (e.g. mesopredators).
Hypothesis_label: Hyperabundance due to anthropogenic food (aka predator subsidy consumption aka prey hyperabundance) hypothesis
Lokatis_name: Hyperabundance due to anthropogenic food* (aka predator subsidy consumption aka prey hyperabundance)
Lokatis_definition: An increase in the proportion of anthropogenic food with urbanization leads to an increase in the abundance of prey as well as mid-sized animals (e.g. mesopredators).
Lokatis_comments: Originally two hypotheses: "Predator subsidy consumption: The proportion of anthropogenic food in the diet of mesopredators will increase with urbanization. Predation rates on vertebrates preyed on by mesopredators will decline with urbanization. Prey hyperabundance: The proportion of anthropogenic food in the diet of some prey species will increase with urbanization. The abundance of these species will increase with urbanization. The predation rate on these species will decline with urbanization." p. 816 in Fischer et al. 2012

Definition: Species that live in close proximity to humans are more successful in invading new areas than other species.
Lokatis_definition: Species that live in close proximity to humans are more successful in invading new areas than other species.
Lokatis_comments: Application to cities: Møller et al. 2015
Daly_definition: Human commensalism is positively related to invasion success (Jeschke and Strayer 2006).
Daly_example_1: Many rats have a commensal relationship with humans that have allowed them to spread and survive over much of the globe (Puckett et al. 2020).
Enders_definition: Species that live in close proximity to humans are more successful in invading new areas than other species

Definition: Biodiversity in urban areas is high due to habitat diversity.
Lokatis_definition: Biodiversity in urban areas is high due to habitat diversity.
Lokatis_comments: "Larger cities are characterized by a greater intensity of the anthropic pressure and higher diversity of habitats.  The typical urban biotopes are combined with the suburban areas of rural character, which contributes to the flora enrichment." Pysek 1989, p.332

Definition: Herbivores may become hyperabundant in urban areas, sometimes leading to pest outbreaks.
Lokatis_definition: Herbivores may become hyperabundant in urban areas, sometimes leading to pest outbreaks.
Lokatis_comments: ﻿For herbivore arthropods (Raupp 2010, p20): "Dramatically elevated densities have been documented frequently in urban forests by herbivorous arthropods that rarely, if ever, reach high densities in natural forests " and  ﻿"Herbivore outbreaks in urban environments have been linked to improved host quality resulting from environmental stress ﻿associated with impervious surfaces and elevated temperatures, as well as escape from natural enemies."

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species in the new area is high if they are pre-adapted to this area
Daly_definition: Traits evolved in the native range can facilitate the invasion of non-native species into novel environments through preadaptation (Mack 2003).
Daly_example_1: Vegetative traits evolved in invasive Himalayan balsam's Impatiens glandulifera native range contributed to its invasion success (Elst et al. 2016).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species in the new area is high if they are pre-adapted to this area

Definition: More isolated habitat islands have lower species richness.
Lokatis_definition: More isolated habitat islands have lower species richness.
Lokatis_comments: "The decrease of the inter-patch distance we observed in town is not indicative of a decrease in habitat patch isolation since patches in urbanised areas are closer to each other but separated by a matrix of built surface which may be a more important barrier to dispersal" Croci et al. 2008a, p.1181

Definition: Land cover change in urban areas favours homogenized communities with a high proportion of non-native, ubiquitous species.
Lokatis_definition: Land cover change in urban areas favours homogenized communities with a high proportion of non-native, ubiquitous species.

Definition: Non-native species establishment and expansion can be limited by land-management activities and cessation of these human activities can release non-native species, facilitating expansion.
Daly_definition: Non-native species establishment and expansion can be limited by land-management activities and cessation of these human activities can release non-native species, facilitating expansion (Zimmermann et al. 2014).
Daly_example_1: Abandonment of agricultural land, and related land management activities, in rural Hungary allowed the proliferation of previously suppressed invasive Plants (Pándi et al. 2014).

Definition: Many species maintain smaller home ranges in urban areas.
Key_ref: Mannan & Boal 2000; Atwood et al. 2004; Wright et al. 2012
Lokatis_definition: Many species maintain smaller home ranges in urban areas.
Lokatis_key_ref: Mannan & Boal 2000; Atwood et al. 2004; Wright et al. 2012
Lokatis_comments: "both suburban/exurban and rural coyotes configure home ranges to minimize exposure to human development and matrix habitat, thereby reducing exposure to humans" (Atwood et al.  2004)

Hypothesis: Shift toward generalist species* aka Habitat specialist
Definition: Urban environments typically favor generalists over specialists.
Key_ref: Sorace 2009; Adler & Tanner 2013; Lowry et al. 2013; Concepción 2015; Elek & Lövei 2007; Klausnitzer 1987; Magura et al. 2004
Hypothesis_label: Shift toward generalist species aka Habitat specialist hypothesis
Lokatis_name: Shift toward generalist species* aka Habitat specialist
Lokatis_definition: Urban environments typically favor generalists over specialists.
Lokatis_key_ref: Sorace 2009, Adler & Tanner 2013 p. 205, Lowry et al. 2013, Concepción 2015, Elek & Lövei 2007, Klausnitzer 1987, Magura et al. 2004

Definition: Hybridization of introduced species with native or non-native species can promote invasiveness in the novel range.
Daly_definition: Hybridization of introduced species with native or non-native species can promote invasiveness in the novel range.

Definition: Animals tend to become bolder in urban than non-urban areas.
Key_ref: Knight et al. 1987; Uchida et al. 2019
Lokatis_definition: Animals tend to become bolder in urban than non-urban areas.
Lokatis_key_ref: Knight et al. 1987; Uchida et al. 2019
Lokatis_comments: Knight et al. 1987: "We examined two complementary hypotheses: (1) in an area of high human density and low persecution, crows should habituate to human beings near their nests and (2) in areas of high persecution, crows should show avoidance behavior to human intruders near their nests".

Definition: Biodiversity is high in sites that show intermediate levels of disturbance and decreases with no and high levels of management.
Lokatis_definition: Biodiversity is high in sites that show intermediate levels of disturbance and decreases with no and high levels of management.
Lokatis_comments: Application to cities: Kowarik 1990; Blair 1996; McKinney 2008; Fig. 2 in Grime 1973 first (?) graphical representation; name coined (?) in Connell 1978, p. 1303: "Diversity is higher when disturbances are intermediate on the scales of frequency and intensity (the "intermediate disturbance" hypothesis)."

Definition: The presence of non-native species in an ecosystem facilitates invasion by additional species, increasing their likelihood of survival or ecological impact
Daly_definition: Previously introduced species may facilitate the establishment of newly introduced species resulting in invasional meltdown (Simberloff and Von Holle 1999).
Daly_example_1: Invasive soil microbiota can change soil conditions such that they are less hospitable for native microbes than other non-native species, potentially causing in invasional meltdown (Zhang et al. 2020).
Daly_example_2: In North America's Great Lakes, many invasive species interactive positively with each other. For example, Eurasian macrophytes provide substrate to Asian bryozoans which may have facilitated their spread (Ricciardi 2001).
Enders_definition: The presence of non-native species in an ecosystem facilitates invasion by additional species, increasing their likelihood of survival or ecological impact

Definition: Eurasian species have better invasion success relative to other species because of coevolution with Europeans and their associated species, which were globally dispersed during European imperialism.
Daly_definition: Eurasian species have better invasion success relative to other species because of coevolution with Europeans and their associated species, which were globally dispersed during European imperialism (Crosby 1986, Jeschke and Strayer 2005).

Definition: Inbreeding in introduced populations can lead to inbreeding depression, potentially inhibiting long term establishment and expansion.
Daly_definition: Inbreeding in introduced populations can lead to inbreeding depression, potentially inhibiting long term establishment and expansion (Willi et al. 2006).

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of resources
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of resources

Hypothesis: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species
Definition: Non-native species richness increases with urbanization.
Lokatis_name: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species
Lokatis_definition: Non-native species richness increases with urbanization.

Definition: Non-native species are more likely to become established and have major ecological impacts on islands than on continents
Daly_definition: Island ecosystems have higher susceptibility to ecological impacts from biological invasion than continents (Jeschke 2008).
Enders_definition: Non-native species are more likely to become established and have major ecological impacts on islands than on continents

Definition: If a non-native species has a lower genetic diversity than the native species, there will be a low probability that the non-native species establishes itself
Enders_definition: If a non-native species has a lower genetic diversity than the native species, there will be a low probability that the non-native species establishes itself

Definition: There are specific traits that make species successful in urban ecosystems.
Lokatis_definition: There are specific traits that make species successful in urban ecosystems.
Lokatis_key_ref: Adler & Tanner 2013, pp. 202; for key references on sub-hypotheses see supplement
Lokatis_comments: see Fischer et al. (2015) for terminology questions related to urban dwellers vs. urban exploiters vs. urban adapters

Definition: The invasion success of a non-native species depends on its specific traits (e.g., life-history traits)
Daly_definition: Species invasiveness, the propensity of a non-native species to become invasive, is determined by the performance, originality, and/or plasticity of traits (Elton 1958, Rejmánek and Richardson 1996, Alpert et al. 2000, van Kleunen et al. 2010)  see also ‘Ideal weed'.
Daly_example_1: Plant traits such as reproductive ability, growth form, seed morphology, and dispersal ability can all influence invasiveness (Richardson and Pyšek 2006).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of a non-native species depends on its specific traits (e.g., life-history traits)

Definition: Species with shorter generation times might adapt faster to the urban environment.
Lokatis_definition: Species with shorter generation times might adapt faster to the urban environment.

Definition: Animals adjust their behavior and activity to avoid humans spatio-temporally.
Key_ref: Brown et al. 1999; Laundré et al. 2010; Bleicher 2017
Lokatis_definition: Animals adjust their behavior and activity to avoid humans spatio-temporally.
Lokatis_key_ref: Brown et al. 1999; Laundré et al. 2010; Bleicher 2017
Lokatis_comments: Stillfried et al. 2017 for application in urban environments

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species is high if they strongly differ from native species, and low if they are similar to native species
Daly_definition: Non-native species expand into new areas by filling an empty niche (Elton 1958) and non-native species will be unlikely to establish in a community dominated by functionally similar species because of greater niche overlap (MacArthur and Levins 1967, Abrams 1983, Stachowicz and Tilman 2005).
Daly_example_1: Phenological traits can allow non-native species to exploit a resource earlier (empty niche), and potentially longer, than native species. This has been observed in native vs. non-native members of family Torymidae in France (Gidoin et al. 2015) and with members of the genus Acer in North America (Paquette et al. 2012).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species is high if they strongly differ from native species, and low if they are similar to native species

Definition: Light pollution alters social interactions and group dynamics of animals.
Hypothesis_label: Light at night - social interaction hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: Light pollution alters social interactions and group dynamics of animals.
Lokatis_comments: Kurvers & Hoelker 2015 also address cities

Definition: Invasive populations can disrupt mutualistic interactions between native species in their introduced ranges. Disruptions may also take place at the community scale (‘Keystone Mutualist Hypothesis' (Gilbert 1980)).
Daly_definition: Invasive populations can disrupt mutualistic interactions between native species in their introduced ranges (Traveset and Richardson 2006). Disruptions may also take place at the community scale (‘Keystone Mutualist Hypothesis' (Gilbert 1980)).

Definition: Urbanization reduces exposure of humans to environmental microbiota.
Key_ref: Ruiz-Calderon et al. 2016; Parajuli et al. 2018
Lokatis_definition: Urbanization reduces exposure of humans to environmental microbiota.
Lokatis_key_ref: Ruiz-Calderon et al. 2016; Parajuli et al. 2018
Lokatis_comments: "Westernization has propelled changes in urbanization and architecture, altering our exposure to the outdoor environment from that experienced during most of human evolution. These changes might affect the developmental exposure of infants to bacteria, immune development, and human microbiome diversity" Ruiz-Calderon et al. 2016 p.1/7; "These remarkable changes in house microbial content across urbanization might translate into differences in microbial exposure that may have developmental health implications for humans (17), according to several related hypotheses [...], suggesting that the reduced pattern ofmicrobial exposure leads to immune and metabolic disorders that have become the new disease paradigm in the industrialized world." Ruiz-Calderon et al. 2016, p.5/7

Definition: In their exotic range, non-native species suffer from missing mutualists
Daly_definition: The fitness of non-native species may be reduced in the novel range due to missing mutualistic interaction partners from the native range (Mitchell et al. 2006). Co-introduction of mutualists may be necessary for invasive success (Hui and Richardson 2017).
Enders_definition: In their exotic range, non-native species suffer from missing mutualists

Definition: New relationships between non-native and native species can positively or negatively influence the establishment of the non-native species
Daly_definition: Novel interactions that occur in new combinations of native and non-native species influence the establishment and success of non-natives (Poyet et al. 2015). These novel interactions often occur through ecological fitting (Hui and Richardson 2017).
Daly_example_1: Numerous novel trophic interactions appear between native fleshy-fruited Plants and the invasive fruit fly Drosophila suzukii (Poyet et al. 2015).
Daly_example_2: Non-native Plants can inhibit mycorrhizal growth and activity, which disrupts the mutualistic mycorrhizal-native plant relationship and indirectly inhibit native plant growth (Vogelsang and Bever 2009).
Enders_definition: New relationships between non-native and native species can positively or negatively influence the establishment of the non-native species

Definition: Urban environments have novel communities that do not exist in natural environments.
Lokatis_definition: Urban environments have novel communities that do not exist in natural environments.

Definition: Invasion may be inhibited when non-native species are at increased susceptibility to consumption due to consumer preference and lack of effective defences.
Key_ref: Colautti et al. 2004; Parker and Hay 2005
Daly_definition: Invasion may be inhibited when non-native species are at increased susceptibility to consumption due to consumer preference and lack of effective defences (Colautti et al. 2004, Parker and Hay 2005).

Hypothesis: Nonnative species richness increases in response to human activity
Definition: Nonnative species increase with human impact hemeroby in cities (functional dimension)
Lokatis_name: Nonnative species richness increases in response to human activity
Lokatis_subhyp_of: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: Nonnative species increase with human impact hemeroby in cities (functional dimension)
Comments_equivalent_hypotheses: TH: PP is too different in my opinion, I would vote against equivalence

Definition: Non-native species similar to residents can become ‘sleeper' invasives, waiting for disturbance to facilitate expansion, as similarity ensures habitat suitability. See also the concept of ‘invasion debt'.
Daly_definition: Non-native species similar to residents can become ‘sleeper' invasives, waiting for disturbance to facilitate expansion, as similarity ensures habitat suitability (Hui et al. 2016). See also the concept of ‘invasion debt'.

Definition: Nonnative Plants in urban areas can sometimes substitute the loss of ressources provided by native Plants.
Lokatis_definition: Nonnative Plants in urban areas can sometimes substitute the loss of ressources provided by native Plants.
Lokatis_comments: "the resources a plant provides are more important than its origin" Berthon et al. 2021

Hypothesis: Nonnative species richness increases along the rural-urban gradient
Definition: Nonnative species increase along the rural-urban gradient spatial dimension
Lokatis_name: Nonnative species richness increases along the rural-urban gradient
Lokatis_subhyp_of: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: Nonnative species increase along the rural-urban gradient spatial dimension

Definition: In the exotic range, non-native species can have a competitive advantage against native species because they possess a novel weapon, that is, a trait that is new to the resident community of native species and, therefore, affects them negatively
Daly_definition: Novel weapons, such as chemical or biological defences, evolved in a species' native range may have a greater effect in its novel range where other species are naïve to them (Callaway and Ridenour 2004).
Enders_definition: In the exotic range, non-native species can have a competitive advantage against native species because they possess a novel weapon, that is, a trait that is new to the resident community of native species and, therefore, affects them negatively

Definition: Invasive species are better able to exploit niche opportunities generated by human activities than most native species.
Lokatis_subhyp_of: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: Invasive species are better able to exploit niche opportunities generated by human activities than most native species.

Definition: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range, and the availability of these niches fluctuates spatio-temporally
Daly_definition: The opportunity window for successful invasion fluctuates as niche availability varies spatiotemporally (Johnstone 1986). See also NICHER and FLUC.
Daly_example_1: Reductions in local graminoid populations due to drought can provide an opportunity window facilitating the establishment and expansion an exotic grass (Manea et al. 2016).
Enders_definition: The invasion success of non-native species increases with the availability of empty niches in the exotic range, and the availability of these niches fluctuates spatio-temporally

Definition: Alien arthropods proliferate on "naive" native host Plants.
Lokatis_subhyp_of: Non-native species hypothesis* aka Invader species hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: Alien arthropods proliferate on "naive" native host Plants.

Definition: Invasive species are more phenotypically plastic than non-invasive or native ones
Key_ref: Richards, Bossdorf, Muth, Gurevitch, and Pigliucci 2006
Daly_definition: Invasive species have greater phenotypic plasticity in ecologically important traits than non-invasive ones, and populations of invasive species are expected to evolve greater plasticity in their invasive range compared to populations within the native range, which facilitate invasion (Richards et al. 2006, Torchyk and Jeschke 2018).
Daly_example_1: Invasive populations of Acer negundo expressed greater plasticity for diameter growth and phenological sensitivity (Lamarque et al. 2015).
Enders_definition: Invasive species are more phenotypically plastic than non-invasive or native ones
Enders_key_ref: Richards, Bossdorf, Muth, Gurevitch, and Pigliucci (2006)

Definition: A higher proportion of alien taxa in captivity and cultivation leads to an increased propagule pressure in cities.
Hypothesis_label: High propagule pressure in cities hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: A higher proportion of alien taxa in captivity and cultivation leads to an increased propagule pressure in cities.
Lokatis_comments: Repeated introductions of the same species at a location (propagule pressure) can increase the likelihood of successful establishment

Definition: The abundance of alien Plants in the urban core encourages native arthropods (herbivores, pollinators) to switch from native to alien host.
Lokatis_definition: The abundance of alien Plants in the urban core encourages native arthropods (herbivores, pollinators) to switch from native to alien host.
Lokatis_comments: "﻿the mainly native [Lepidoptera] species commonly observed in gardens breed mostly or entirely on alien Plants, especially naturalized weeds. Over 40% of the fauna has no known native hosts in the urban–suburban environment." Shapiro 2002 (p31); "﻿Countering this trend for reduced herbivore richness and abundance on exotic Plants are specialists that switch from indigenous congeners to alien Plants, as well as native generalists that incorporate introduced Plants into their diet" Raupp 2010 (p23)

Definition: Polyploid organisms, particularly Plants, are predicted to have an increased invasion success, since polyploidy can lead to higher fitness during the establishment phase and/or increased potential for subsequent adaptation
Enders_definition: Polyploid organisms, particularly Plants, are predicted to have an increased invasion success, since polyploidy can lead to higher fitness during the establishment phase and/or increased potential for subsequent adaptation

Definition: A high propagule pressure (a composite measure consisting of the number of individuals introduced per introduction event and the frequency of introduction events) is a cause of invasion success
Daly_definition: High propagule pressure, the number of introduced individuals, species, and/or introduction events, is a major determinant of the establishment and further colonization success of invasive species (Simberloff 2009, Bulleri et al. 2019).
Daly_example_1: Propagule pressures in the range of 10–100 individuals have a critical positive effect on invasion success for diverse invertebrates, trees, herbaceous Plants, and both terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates (Cassey et al. 2018).
Enders_definition: A high propagule pressure (a composite measure consisting of the number of individuals introduced per introduction event and the frequency of introduction events) is a cause of invasion success

Definition: Urban habitats serve as sinks for rural dispersers. Continuous gene flow between rural source and urban sink populations prohibits pronounced genetic differentiation.
Lokatis_definition: Urban habitats serve as sinks for rural dispersers. Continuous gene flow between rural source and urban sink populations prohibits pronounced genetic differentiation.
Lokatis_comments: "The  population  pressure hypothesis PPH postulates that  urban foxes are simply  in truders from the adjacent rural areas. These foxes invade in human settlements because of a  high population  density in rural areas. According to the PPH, urban areas would provide  suboptimal  habitats for foxes, the dynamics of an urban fox population would closely correlate with the trend of the fox population in the adjacent  rural areas,  and the urban fox population would  genetically not be different  from the adjacent  rural population" Gloor et al. 2001, p161

Definition: Predator density, prey mortality and/or prey fearfulness are lower in urban than non-urban areas.
Key_ref: Tomialojc 1982; Gering & Blair 1999; Shochat et al. 2006; Fischer et al. 2012; Eötvös et al. 2018
Lokatis_definition: Predator density, prey mortality and/or prey fearfulness are lower in urban than non-urban areas.
Lokatis_key_ref: Tomialojc 1982; Gering & Blair 1999; Shochat et al. 2006; Fischer et al. 2012; Eötvös et al. 2018

Definition: Predator densities and/or predation rates are higher in urban than non-urban areas.
Key_ref: Fischer et al. 2012; Sorace 2002; Eötvös et al. 2018
Lokatis_definition: Predator densities and/or predation rates are higher in urban than non-urban areas.
Lokatis_key_ref: Fischer et al. 2012 based on Sorace 2002; Eötvös et al. 2018

Definition: "The diet of carnivorous mesopredators will be increasingly dominated by a few species with urbanization. These prey species will be hyperabundant within cities. The predation rate on prey species that are not hyperabundant will decline with urbanization." (p. 816 in Fischer et al. 2012)
Lokatis_definition: "The diet of carnivorous mesopredators will be increasingly dominated by a few species with urbanization. These prey species will be hyperabundant within cities. The predation rate on prey species that are not hyperabundant will decline with urbanization." (p. 816 in Fischer et al. 2012)

Definition: Urban dwellers are preadapted to urban environments, i.e. they already possessed beneficial traits (e.g. drought resistance) outside of cities that are advantageous in urban environments.
Lokatis_definition: Urban dwellers are preadapted to urban environments, i.e. they already possessed beneficial traits (e.g. drought resistance) outside of cities that are advantageous in urban environments.
Comments_equivalent_hypotheses:
TH: I also see some equivalence here - discuss?
MBV: I don't know about equivalence, but perhaps analogous to preadaptation in invasion biology

Definition: Lethal mutations and part of the mutation load can be purged in small populations (Glémin 2003), such as founding populations of introduced species (Willi et al. 2006).
Daly_definition: Lethal mutations and part of the mutation load can be purged in small populations (Glémin 2003), such as founding populations of introduced species (Willi et al. 2006).

Definition: Rates of evolutionary change are greater in urbanizing systems.
Lokatis_definition: Rates of evolutionary change are greater in urbanizing systems.
Lokatis_comments: "We hypothesize that shifts in the physical and socioeconomic structure and function of large urban complexes can drive rapid evolution of many species that play important roles in communities and ecosystems." Alberti et al. 2017 p8951; "Urbanization affects adaptive and nonadaptive evolutionary processes that shape the genetic diversity within and between populations." Johnson & Munshi-South 2017
Comments: "We find that rates of phenotypic change are greater in anthropogenic contexts than in natural contexts." Hendry et al. 2008

Definition: The non-native species is released from its natural enemies and can spend more energy in its reproduction, and invasion success increases with the availability of resources
Daly_definition: Fast growing species with weak defences against enemies benefit experience disproportionate success through the interaction of increased resources and enemy release in the novel range (Blumenthal 2005).
Enders_definition: The non-native species is released from its natural enemies and can spend more energy in its reproduction, and invasion success increases with the availability of resources

Definition: A population of a non-native species that is highly successful shortly after its introduction can decline or disappear over time due to different reasons (such as competition with other introduced species or adaptation by native species)
Enders_definition: A population of a non-native species that is highly successful shortly after its introduction can decline or disappear over time due to different reasons (such as competition with other introduced species or adaptation by native species)

Definition: Urban dwellers generally have a higher reproductive output than urban visitors also outside of cities.
Lokatis_definition: Urban dwellers generally have a higher reproductive output than urban visitors also outside of cities.
Comments_equivalent_hypotheses: TH: I would not say there is equivalence

Definition: "Resilience in urban ecosystems is a function of the patterns of human activities and natural habitats that control and are controlled by both socio-economic and biophysical processes operating at various scales". (p. 242 in Alberti & Marzluff 2004)
Hypothesis_label: Resilience of urban hybrid systems hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: "Resilience in urban ecosystems is a function of the patterns of human activities and natural habitats that control and are controlled by both socio-economic and biophysical processes operating at various scales". (p. 242 in Alberti & Marzluff 2004)

Definition: Species richness and diversity increase with habitat size.
Lokatis_definition: Species richness and diversity increase with habitat size.
Lokatis_comments: Application to cities: Davis & Glick 1978; Gaublomme et al. 2008; MacGregor‐Fors et al. 2011

Definition: Streets act as dispersal barriers.
Lokatis_definition: Streets act as dispersal barriers.
Lokatis_comments: Application to cities: Riley et al. 2014

Definition: Streets act as dispersal corridors.
Key_ref: Seabrook & Dettmann 1996; James & Stuart-Smith 2000; Von der Lippe et al. 2013
Lokatis_definition: Streets act as dispersal corridors.
Lokatis_key_ref: Seabrook & Dettmann 1996; James & Stuart-Smith 2000; Von der Lippe et al. 2013

Definition: After having been released from natural specialist enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy to cheap (energy-inexpensive) defences against generalist enemies and less energy to expensive defences against specialist enemies (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes); the energy gained in this way will be invested in growth and/or reproduction, which makes the non-native species more competitive
Daly_definition: Under lower pressure by enemies in the invaded range, species can shift defenses against specialist predators to less costly defenses against generalists (Müller-Schärer 2004, Joshi and Vrieling 2005).
Enders_definition: After having been released from natural specialist enemies, non-native species will allocate more energy to cheap (energy-inexpensive) defences against generalist enemies and less energy to expensive defences against specialist enemies (this re-allocation is due to genetic changes); the energy gained in this way will be invested in growth and/or reproduction, which makes the non-native species more competitive

Definition: Non-native species are more successful in a new region if the local predators are specialists and local mutualists are generalists
Daly_definition: Non-native species are more successful in a new region if the local predators are specialists and local mutualists are generalists (Callaway et al. 2008).
Enders_definition: Non-native species are more successful in a new region if the local predators are specialists and local mutualists are generalists

Definition: The proportion of synanthropic species in cities increases towards the north.
Lokatis_definition: The proportion of synanthropic species in cities increases towards the north.

Definition: Urbanization favors non-migratory species.
Lokatis_definition: Urbanization favors non-migratory species.

Definition: Mating between individuals with high dispersal ability at the leading edge of invasion may lead to natural selection and novel phenotypes due to spatial sorting.
Key_ref: Shine et al. 2011; Phillips and Perkins 2019
Daly_definition: Mating between individuals with high dispersal ability at the leading edge of invasion may lead to natural selection and novel phenotypes due to spatial sorting (Shine et al. 2011, Phillips and Perkins 2019).

Definition: A large number of different non-native species is more likely to become invasive than a small number due to interspecific competition. Also, the species identity of the locals is more important than the richness in terms of the invasion of an area
Enders_definition: A large number of different non-native species is more likely to become invasive than a small number due to interspecific competition. Also, the species identity of the locals is more important than the richness in terms of the invasion of an area

Definition: Introduced species may carry parasites that go on to infect local species (‘spillover') and may also catch and amplify a part of local parasites, then constituting reservoirs for parasite transmission and acting as hosts to ultimately release them into ecosystem (‘spillback').
Key_ref: Daszak et al. 2000; Eppinga et al. 2006; Amsellem et al. 2017
Daly_definition: Introduced species may carry parasites that go on to infect local species (‘spillover') and may also catch and amplify a part of local parasites, then constituting reservoirs for parasite transmission and acting as hosts to ultimately release them into ecosystem (‘spillback') (Daszak et al. 2000, Eppinga et al. 2006, Amsellem et al. 2017).

Definition: Species richness is positively correlated with human population density.
Hypothesis_label: Species richness - HPD (human population density) hypothesis
Lokatis_definition: Species richness is positively correlated with human population density.
Lokatis_comments: Application to cities: Kuussaari et al. 2021

Definition: The number of synanthropic species increases along the rural-urban gradient.
Lokatis_definition: The number of synanthropic species increases along the rural-urban gradient.
Lokatis_comments: Klausnitzer 1987, p. 103: Hemerophile Arten siedeln vorzugsweise in von Menschen gestalteter Landschaft

Definition: Species richness is highest in sub-urban areas; it is lower in urban centers and the (rural) periphery.
Lokatis_definition: Species richness is highest in sub-urban areas; it is lower in urban centers and the (rural) periphery.
Lokatis_comments: "Many of the species that were able to invade locally at moderate levels of urbanization also went locally extinct with more intense urbanization." p. 53 in Blair 2001

Definition: Approximately 10% of species successfully take consecutive steps of the invasion process
Enders_definition: Approximately 10% of species successfully take consecutive steps of the invasion process

Definition: Thermal tolerance increases with urbanization.
Lokatis_definition: Thermal tolerance increases with urbanization.
Lokatis_comments: Mechanistically, these shifts in thermal tolerance under urbanization reflected both evolutionary change and phenotypic plasticity, as ants from urban areas exhibited higher thermal tolerances compared with ants from rural areas regardless of rearing temperature, and ants reared in the warmer temperature treatment exhibited higher tolerances than ants reared in the cooler temperature treatment.

Definition: Urban avoiders have a reduced ability to adapt, compete and/or reproduce in cities.
Lokatis_definition: Urban avoiders have a reduced ability to adapt, compete and/or reproduce in cities.

Definition: Species composition of different cities will become more and more similar as urbanization increases.
Lokatis_definition: Species composition of different cities will become more and more similar as urbanization increases.
Lokatis_comments: "urbanization leads to the local extinction of species and invasion by other species and, consequently, creates more homogeneous faunal communities" p. 34 in Blair 2001

Definition: The abundance of alien Plants in the urban core tends to reduce the richness and abundance of native herbivore insects incapable of using non-native Plants.
Lokatis_definition: The abundance of alien Plants in the urban core tends to reduce the richness and abundance of native herbivore insects incapable of using non-native Plants.
Lokatis_comments: ﻿"In general, the proportion of alien Plants in a landscape increases with increasing levels of urbanization, which may negatively affect the diversity and abundance of herbivores in urban settings" Raupp et al. 2010 (p23)
Comments: "Together, these assumptions predict that alien Plants will support a smaller load of specialist insect herbivores than will native congeners and a smaller load of general- ists than will native Plants in general." Tallamy 2004 (p1690);  "landscapes dominated by non-native Plants, whether unwanted invasives or desirable ornamentals, are unlikely to support the same diversity and biomass of insect herbivores as landscapes dominated by native host Plants." Burghardt et al. 2009 (p220)

Definition: Diversity typically increases as the number of individuals increase in biological communities. Urban environments, however, tend to be characterized by lower biodiversity than wildlands despite high population densities.
Key_ref: Shochat et al. 2010; Saari et al. 2016
Lokatis_definition: Diversity typically increases as the number of individuals increase in biological communities. Urban environments, however, tend to be characterized by lower biodiversity than wildlands despite high population densities.
Lokatis_key_ref: Shochat et al. 2010; Saari et al. 2016

Definition: All ecosystems types respond to urban land use in a convergent manner (in other words: urban ecosystems are convergent regardless of the original ecosystem they replaced).
Lokatis_definition: All ecosystems types respond to urban land use in a convergent manner (in other words: urban ecosystems are convergent regardless of the original ecosystem they replaced).
Lokatis_comments: "We suggest an 'urban ecosystem convergence hypothesis', where urbanization drives ecosystem structure and function (e.g., SOC pools, leaf area index), toward a range of similar endpoints over time regardless of ecosystem life zone starting points" Pouyat et al. 2003, P.358

Definition: Through urbanization, humans mediate the interactions and feedback between evolution and ecology in subtle ways by introducing changes in habitat, biotic interactions, heterogeneity, novel disturbance, and social interactions. (p. 116 in Alberti 2015)
Lokatis_definition: "Through urbanization, humans mediate the interactions and feedback between evolution and ecology in subtle ways by introducing changes in habitat, biotic interactions, heterogeneity, novel disturbance, and social interactions." (p. 116 in Alberti 2015)

Definition: Urbanization leads to a reduction in ecosystem functions and services.
Lokatis_definition: Urbanization leads to a reduction in ecosystem functions and services.

Definition: The number of non-native species moving through each invasion stage (transport, introduction, esttablishment, spread) is higher in urban areas than in natural environments.
Lokatis_definition: The number of non-native species moving through each invasion stage (transport, introduction, esttablishment, spread) is higher in urban areas than in natural environments.
Lokatis_comments: In urban areas, the relative effectiveness of the barriers to invasion is diminished (to varying degrees) allowing a greater proportion of species to move through each subsequent invasion stage, i.e. “the urban effect” on invasion.

Definition: Urbanization leads to a loss of genetic variation within and increased differentiation between populations
Lokatis_definition: Urbanization leads to a loss of genetic variation within and increased differentiation between populations
Lokatis_comments: "Urbanization‐driven habitat fragmentation is expected to increase genetic drift within populations and reduce gene flow between populations. Consequently, urban habitat fragmentation is predicted to reduce genetic diversity within populations and increase genetic differentiation among populations under a standard neutral model" Miles et al. 2019

Definition: Native species can switch to urban habitats.
Lokatis_definition: Native species can switch to urban habitats.
Comments: Work on apophytism (in Plants, e.g. Thellung 1919) or synantropy (in animals); Lundholm & Richardson 2010 state the same for industrial environments

Definition: Cities are often located in areas of high biodiversity and urbanization is disproportionally higher in areas with high biodiversity.
Key_ref: Kühn et al. 2004; Luck 2007; Ives et al. 2016
Lokatis_definition: Cities are often located in areas of high biodiversity and urbanization is disproportionally higher in areas with high biodiversity.
Lokatis_key_ref: Kühn et al. 2004; Luck 2007; Ives et al. 2016
Lokatis_comments: This hypothesis explicitly embraces the concept of biodiversity hot spots, which refers to biodiverse areas that are threatened by human intervention (and thus "hot spots" of biodiversity, see https://www.conservation.org/priorities/biodiversity-hotspots)

Definition: "The abundance of large-bodied predators will decline with urbanization, whereas the abundance of mesopredators will increase." (p. 816 in Fischer et al. 2012)
Lokatis_definition: "The abundance of large-bodied predators will decline with urbanization, whereas the abundance of mesopredators will increase." (p. 816 in Fischer et al. 2012)
Lokatis_comments:
Similar (but not under the name of  'mesopredator release'): "In the background desert, bottom-up or resource-based forces dominate the food web, but in the urbanized region, top-down or predatory forces combine with bottom-up forces to control trophic
dynamics." (p. 403, Fig. 3, Faeth et al. 2005)
Lokatis_key_ref_overarching: Soulé et al. 1988; Prugh et al. 2009
Comments: "In the absence of large, dominant predators, smaller omnivores and predators undergo population explosions, sometimes becoming four to 10 times more abundant than normal" (p. 83 in Soulé et al. 1988)

Definition: Urban adapted species may be more likely to become invasive because they may be better adapted to future environments because of urban climate conditions (Borden and Flory 2021)
Daly_definition: Urban adapted species may be more likely to become invasive because they may be better adapted to future environments because of urban climate conditions (Borden and Flory 2021)

Definition: Urban competition may increase competitiveness of urban adapted species, which may facilitate their success as invaders (Borden and Flory 2021).
Daly_definition: Urban competition may increase competitiveness of urban adapted species, which may facilitate their success as invaders (Borden and Flory 2021).

Hypothesis: Urban ecosystems as source of innovation*
Definition: "The hybrid nature of urban ecosystems – resulting from co-evolving human and natural systems – is a source of ‘innovation’ in eco-evolutionary processes. " (p. 117 in Alberti 2015)
Hypothesis_label: Urban ecosystems as source of innovation hypothesis
Lokatis_name: Urban ecosystems as source of innovation*
Lokatis_definition: "The hybrid nature of urban ecosystems – resulting from co-evolving human and natural systems – is a source of ‘innovation’ in eco-evolutionary processes. " (p. 117 in Alberti 2015)

Definition: In urban environments, species show shifts in several traits related to sexual selection (particularly in their coloration, acoustic signals including songs and calls, hormones, pheromones, mating behaviour).
Lokatis_definition: In urban environments, species show shifts in several traits related to sexual selection (particularly in their coloration, acoustic signals including songs and calls, hormones, pheromones, mating behaviour).
Lokatis_comments: e.g., colouration: forest great tits with wider black ties survive better, but the reverse was found for urban birds (Senar et al. 2014)

Definition: Biodiversity loss in cities is largely associated with a low tolerance of species to urbanization.
Lokatis_definition: Biodiversity loss in cities is largely associated with a low tolerance of species to urbanization.

Definition: The abundance of xerophilous species is increasing with urbanization.
Key_ref: Horvath et al. 2012; McGlynn et al. 2019
Lokatis_definition: The abundance of xerophilous species is increasing with urbanization.
Lokatis_key_ref: Horvath et al. 2012, McGlynn et al. 2019
